Certainly, one contemporary example of a story that uses the landscape in a significant way is "The Road" by Cormac McCarthy. The novel is set in a post-apocalyptic world where the landscape is an integral part of the story's narrative, emphasizing the bleak and unforgiving nature of the world.

The world of "The Road" is depicted as a desolate wasteland struggling to survive after an unspecified global disaster. The landscape is portrayed as a lifeless, barren, and harsh environment, where characters must struggle to find the basic necessities of life, such as food and water.

However, even in this bleak landscape, there are still moments of beauty and hope, such as when the characters come across a waterfall or glimpse a small patch of greenery among the ruins. These moments serve to highlight the stark contrast between the world before and after the apocalypse, emphasizing the devastation that has occurred.

Moreover, the landscape serves as a metaphor for the characters' emotional journey, as the father and son struggle to survive and find meaning in a world that has become devoid of hope and purpose.

Overall, through its vivid depiction of the landscape, "The Road" creates a compelling and impactful story that explores the depths of human endurance and the resilience of the human spirit.
